title: View HackerOne challenge scope before challenge begins

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** Hi team, I have come across an issue where I am able to view a HackerOne challenge scope before the challenge begins. The issue here being that I can get an understanding of what the in-scope assets are before a challenge starts, allowing myself to start researching and finding bugs to hold on to until the challenge begins.

You can see this by going to the challenge's `scope_versions` page before the challenge starts and the scope is still hidden: `https://hackerone.com/{challengeName}/scope_versions`

The program policy states the scope will be displayed at a later date
>Congratulations! You've been invited to participate in a HackerOne Challenge. More details around the scope, bounty structure, etc. will be available when the Challenge begins.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. If you have access to a HackerOne challenge (before it starts, while the scope is hidden), access that challenge's `scope_versions` page. The current one I have access to is: â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ
2. Notice you can see the current scope, and scope history of this challenge, displaying the in-scope assets for the challenge prior to release.
â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ

## Impact

This gives an unfair advantage to the researcher's identifying the scope, as they are able to see the in-scope assets for the challenge, allowing them to do recon and research before the scope is announced. Given the limited time for the challenge, this could be used to manipulate the results and gather bugs before the challenge begins.
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary: Hi team, I have come across an issue where I am able to view a HackerOne challenge scope before the challenge begins. The issue here being that I can get an understanding of what the in-scope assets are before a challenge starts, allowing myself to start researching and finding bugs to hold on to until the challenge begins.

You can see this by going to the challenge's scope_versions page before the challenge starts and the scope is still hidden: https://hackerone.com/{challengeName}/scope_versions

The program policy states the scope will be displayed at a later date

Congratulations! You've been invited to participate in a HackerOne Challenge. More details around the scope, bounty structure, etc. will be available when the Challenge begins.

Steps To Reproduce

  1. If you have access to a HackerOne challenge (before it starts, while the scope is hidden), access that challenge's scope_versions page. The current one I have access to is: â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ
  2. Notice you can see the current scope, and scope history of this challenge, displaying the in-scope assets for the challenge prior to release. â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ

Impact

This gives an unfair advantage to the researcher's identifying the scope, as they are able to see the in-scope assets for the challenge, allowing them to do recon and research before the scope is announced. Given the limited time for the challenge, this could be used to manipulate the results and gather bugs before the challenge begins.

activities.message:
Thank you for reporting this potential issue, 

Your report is currently being examined by the HackerOne triage team. You will receive further details, or questions, as soon as technically possible. Thanks for your patience.

Cheers,
@still

activities.message:
Thank you for your submission @neema,

The information you have provided here will be forwarded onto the team. You will receive updates when, and if, there will be any to share. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Cheers, 
@still

activities.message: Hi @neema - thanks again for bringing this to our attention. We determined that this was a human error on our side. We have a process in place that should've stopped this from happening, but we slipped up. We don't believe that this meets the minimum bar for us to award a bounty, so we'll send you some swag instead. Thanks again. Good luck and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @neema - thanks again for bringing this to our attention. We determined that this was a human error on our side. We have a process in place that should've stopped this from happening, but we slipped up. We don't believe that this meets the minimum bar for us to award a bounty, so we'll send you some swag instead. Thanks again. Good luck and happy hacking!

activities.message: Hey @jobert, appreciate it but isnâ€™t this a more severe version of #488643 as that simply revealed the program name while this revealed the assets in scope? Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hey @jobert, appreciate it but isnâ€™t this a more severe version of #488643 as that simply revealed the program name while this revealed the assets in scope? Thanks!

activities.message:
Hey @neema,

We looked into this again, initially we thought that the scopes were put in place in a manual process but that is not the case. So our initial assumption was that it was a mistake in a process that did have security considerations in place was wrong, so sorry about that! On further review, it's definitely a systematic check as you pointed out, that is disclosing the information, the structured scope endpoint is protecting against the challenge kick off, but the structure scope versions endpoint is not. 

Sorry for the mistake, and please note that this will be eligible for bounty ðŸ’°

We'll escalate this to the appropriate team to get it addressed and we'll get back to you about the severity/bounty decision on Friday.

Thanks,
@bencode

Sorry for the mistake, and please note that this will be eligible for bounty ðŸ’°

We'll escalate this to the appropriate team to get it addressed and we'll get back to you about the severity/bounty decision on Friday.
